html: In this chapter, I. More weight is added to the burden of Babylon, enough to sink it like a mill-stone I. It is Israel's cause that is to be pleaded in this quarrel with Babylon, . 2. The king of Babylon, for the time being, shall be remarkably brought down and triumphed over, . 3. The whole race of the Babylonians shall be cut off and extirpated, . II. A confirmation of the prophecy of the destruction of Babylon, which was a thing at a distance, is here given in the prophecy of the destruction of the Assyrian army that invaded the land, which happened not long after, . III. The success of Hezekiah against the Philistines is here foretold, and the advantages which his people would gain thereby, .
